sentences.sentence: He was approaching the door of the house, when it opened, and a little, curly-headed( 卷发的 ) boy of six came running out, followed by a rather fat, red-faced woman with a large sponge( 海绵 ) in her hand.
“You come back and be washed, Jack,” she shouted. “If your father comes home and finds you like that, both of us will be in trouble!”
“Dear little chap( 家伙 )!” said Holmes, strategically. “What a rosy-cheeked young boy! Now, Jack, is there anything you would like?”
The boy thought for a moment. “I’d like a shilling( 先令 ),” he said.
“Nothing you would like better?”
“I’d like two shillings better,” the intelligent boy answered, after some thought.
“Here you are, then! Catch!—An intelligent child, Mrs. Smith!”
“He is that, and cheeky( 厚脸皮的 ) too. He gets almost too much for me to manage, especially when my man is away for days at a time.”
“Away, is he?” said Holmes, in a disappointed voice. “I am sorry about that, for I wanted to speak to Mr. Smith.”
“He’s been away since yesterday morning sir, and, truth to tell, I am beginning to feel frightened( 担忧的 ) about him. But if it was about a boat, sir, you could talk to me.”
“I wanted to hire his steam launch( 汽艇 ).”
“Sir, it is in the steam launch( 汽艇 ) that he has gone.
That’s what puzzles me, for I know there aren’t enough coals in her to take her further than Woolwich.
If he’d been away in the barge( 驳船 ) I’d have thought nothing of it, for many a time a job has taken him as far as Gravesend, and then if there was much to do there he might have stayed over( 过夜 ).
But what good is a steam launch( 汽艇 ) without coals?”
“He might have bought some at a wharf( 码头 ) down the river.”
“He might, sir, but it wasn’t his way.
Many a time I’ve heard him complain( 抱怨 ) the prices they charge just for a few bags.
Besides, I don’t like that wooden-legged man, with his ugly face and his strange talk.
What did he want always coming around here?”
“A wooden-legged man?” said Holmes, with mild surprise.
“Yes, sir, a brown, monkey-faced chap( 家伙 ) that’s called more than once for my old man.
It was him that woke him up yesterday night, and, what’s more, my man knew he was coming, for he had steam up( 使冒蒸汽（这里指启动） ) in the launch( 汽艇 ).
I tell you honestly, sir, I don’t feel easy in my mind about it.”
“But, my dear Mrs. Smith,” said Holmes, shrugging( 耸 ) his shoulders, “you are frightening( 惊吓 ) yourself about nothing.
How could you possibly tell that it was the wooden-legged man who came in the night?
I don’t quite understand how you can be so sure.”
“I knew his voice, sir. He tapped at the window—about three it would be. ‘Show a leg, mate( 伙计 ),’ said he, ‘time to get going.’
My old man woke up Jim—that’s my eldest son—and away they went, without so much as a word to me. I could hear the wooden leg clacking on the stones.”
“And was this wooden-legged man alone?”
“Couldn’t say, I’m sure, sir. I didn’t hear anyone else.”
“I am sorry, Mrs. Smith, for I wanted a steam launch( 汽艇 ), and I have heard good reports of the—Let me see, what is her name?”
“The Aurora, sir.”
“Ah! She’s not that old green launch( 汽艇 ) with a yellow line, very wide( 宽 )?”
“No, indeed. She’s as narrow a little thing as any on the river. She’s been fresh painted, black with two red streaks( 条纹 ).”
“Thanks. I hope that you will hear soon from Mr. Smith. I am going down the river; and if I should see anything of the Aurora I shall let him know that you are uneasy. A black funnel( 烟囱 ), you say?”
“No, sir. Black with a white band.”
“Ah, of course. It was the sides which were black. Good morning, Mrs. Smith.”
“Now, Watson,” he said to me, “let us see if that boatman over there will take us across the river.”
“The main thing with people of that sort,” said Holmes, as we sat in the boat, “is never to let them think that their information can be of the slightest importance to you.
If you do, they will instantly shut up( 闭嘴 ) like an oyster( 牡蛎 ).
If you listen to them under protest( 漫不经心地 ), as it were, you are very likely to( 可能 ) get what you want.”
“Our plan now seems pretty clear,” said I.
“What would you do, then?”
“I would hire a launch( 汽艇 ) and go down the river looking for the Aurora.”
“My dear fellow, it would be an enormous( 繁重的 ) task.
She may have landed at any wharf( 码头 ) on either side of the river between here and the sea.
Below the bridge there is a perfect maze( 错综复杂 ) of landing-places for miles.
It would take you days and days to look at them all, if you tried it alone.”
“Use the police, then.”
“No. I shall probably call Athelney Jones in( 找...帮忙 ) at the last moment.
He is not a bad fellow, and I should not like to do anything which would injure him professionally.
But I would like to work it out myself, now that we have gone so far.”
“Could we ask around among the boat-workers?”
“Worse and worse! Our men would know that we were after them, and they would be off out of the country.
As it is, they are likely enough to leave, but as long as they think they are perfectly safe they will be in no hurry.
Jones’s energy will be of use to us there, for his view of the case is sure to appear in the daily papers, and the runaways will think that everyone is off on the wrong scent( 失去线索 ).”
“What are we to do, then?” I asked, as we landed on the other side.
“Go home, have some breakfast, and get some sleep. We may have to go out again tonight. We will keep Toby, for he may be useful to us yet.”
It was between eight and nine o’clock now, and I was conscious of a strong reaction after the excitements of the night.
I was limp( 无力的 ) and weary( 疲惫的 ), befogged in mind and fatigued( 精疲力竭的 ) in body.
I had not the professional( 职业的 ) enthusiasm which carried my companion on, nor could I look at the matter as a mere abstract intellectual( （需用）智力的 ) problem.
As far as the death of Bartholomew Sholto went, I had heard little good of him, and could not feel great hatred for his murderers.
The treasure, however, was a different matter. That, or part of it, belonged rightfully( 正当地 ) to Miss Morstan.
While there was a chance of recovering it, I was ready to devote my life to that.
True, if I found it, it would probably put her forever beyond my reach.
Yet it would be a petty( 渺小的 ) and selfish love which would be influenced by such a thought as that.
If Holmes could work to find the criminals, I had a tenfold( 十倍的 ) stronger reason to urge me on to find the treasure.

article_info.previous: Holmes继续阐述着他的推理，而Toby一刻不停地追踪着气味，最终气味消失在了一个码头，看来罪犯要比想象中奸诈。
article_info.share_words: Sir, it is in the steam launch that he has gone. That’s what puzzles me, for I know there aren’t enough coals in her to take her further than Woolwich.

question.cn: 小男孩从Holmes那儿得到了什么？
question.en: What did the young boy get from Holmes?

analysis: 文中小孩刚开始说：“I’d like a shilling”，后来Holmes问他还有没有什么更想要的，他便改口说：“I’d like two shillings better”。因此答案选B。

question.en: Did Holmes manage to hire the steam launch?

analysis: 文中Holmes提出：“I wanted to hire his steam launch”，Mrs. Smith回答道：“Sir, it is in the steam launch that he has gone. That’s what puzzles me, for I know there aren’t enough coals in her to take her further than Woolwich. ”因此答案选B。

question.cn: 为什么Mrs. Smith如此肯定夜里来的正是木桩腿男人呢？
question.en: Why was Mrs. Smith so sure that it was the wooden-legged man who had come in the night?

options.cn: 因为她清清楚楚看到了他。
options.en: Because she had seen him clearly.
Because Mr. Smith had told her.

options.cn: 因为她分辨出了他的声音。
options.en: Because she had known his voice.

analysis: 文中Smith夫人说道：“I knew his voice, sir. He tapped at the window—about three it would be. ‘Show a leg, mate,’ said he, ‘time to get going.’ My old man woke up Jim—that’s my eldest son—and away they went, without so much as a word to me. I could hear the wooden leg clacking on the stones”因此答案选C。

question.cn: 为什么他们不去询问船工？
question.en: Why didn’t they ask around among the boat-workers?

options.cn: 因为船工们不了解任何有关情况。
options.en: Because the boat-workers knew nothing about it.

options.cn: 因为这样会耗费很多的时间与金钱。
options.en: Because it would take them a lot of time and money.

options.cn: 因为这样罪犯就会知道有人在追捕他们。
options.en: Because the criminals would know someone was after them.

analysis: 文中Watson提议去询问船工，Holmes说道：“Worse and worse! Our men would know that we were after them, and they would be off out of the country. As it is, they are likely enough to leave, but as long as they think they are perfectly safe they will be in no hurry. ”因此答案选C。

question.cn: 经过这次长达六英里的徒步，Watson感觉怎样？
question.en: How did Watson feel after the six-mile walk?

analysis: 文中提到：“It was between eight and nine o’clock now, and I was conscious of a strong reaction after the excitements of the night. I was limp and weary, befogged in mind and fatigued in body.”因此答案选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第35天
